columns.text: In this exercise, we are asked to assess the IPO underpricing.

The act of issuing an initial public offering (IPO) at a price less than its true market value on the public market is known as **underpricing**. When a new share trades above the specified issue price on its trading date, it is underpriced.

Let us first identify the given amounts in the problem: 


| | Amount$\hspace{5pt}$| 
|:--|--:| 
|Share price | $40.00|
|One is undervalued by | $9.00| 
|One is overvalued by   |$4.00|
|Number of shares to be purchased|1,000|

First, let us determine the profit of the investor if the underpriced shares are rationed and only half of it will be filled. This is computed as follows: 

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Profit}&={{(}}\dfrac{\text{Number of shares}}{\text{2 }}{\text{$\times$ UV)}}{\text{ + (Number of shares $\times$ OV)}}\\

\end{aligned}$$ 
Where: 

UV = Undervalued price

OV = Overpriced value

If the investor will buy 1,000 shares for both underpriced and overvalued shares. The company would have a higher profit, which is computed as follows: 

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Profit}&={{(}}{\text{Number of shares}}{\text{$\times$ UV)}}{\text{ + (Number of shares $\times$ OV)}}\\[5pt]
&={{(}}{\text{1,000}}{\text{$\times$ \$9.00)}}{\text{ + (1,000 $\times$ \$4.00)}}\\[5pt]
&={\textbf{\$13,000.00}}
\end{aligned}$$ 

**The investor expects a profit amounting to $13,000.00 if the company bought 1,000 shares for both underpriced and overvalued shares.**

**To conclude, the principle shown in this exercise is a winner's curse. The investors lose money since the final offer is more than the intrinsic value. Under this principle, the profit is lower than the investor's estimated profit**.
